author: pk910
content:
We might wanna change the contract addresses to some nicer looking ones.
We've generated a set of addresses with a 0x0000...00<eip-number> pattern:
```
eip-2935: 0x0000f90827f1c53a10cb7a02335b175320002935
eip-7251: 0x0000bbddc7ce488642fb579f8b00f3a590007251
eip-7002: 0x00000961ef480eb55e80d19ad83579a64c007002
```
to be discussed on thursday I think ðŸ™‚

author: jochembrouwer
content: Wow, I love this idea ðŸ˜„ Why did we not think of this earlier? ðŸ™‚

author: pk910
content:
the deployment is tied to the contract bytecode,   so for any change we need a new set of addresses..
doesn't really make sense to generate these nicer looking addresses for dev contracts, as there's also quite some cpu time involved ðŸ˜‰

author: jochembrouwer
content:
Ah yes, I know. I actually thought in earlier forks we also deployed these types of contracts but my memory might be failing me (besides the deposit contract). Super creative to add these EIP numbers. The only downside is that you can't checksum the numbers (no lower/uppercase). I'd wonder who thought of adding the EIP numbers to the contract address? ðŸ™‚

Ah ok yes my memory is not mistaken. For EIP-4788 ðŸ™‚ (Beacon block root in EVM). But that's actually deployed at `0x000F3df6D732807Ef1319fB7B8bB8522d0Beac02` so it has a similar pattern also. (I will stop flooding this channel now)
